concept.title: The difference between processes, procedures and tasks
concept.shortdesc: A procedure is a synonym for a task, but a process is an upper level series of major steps, with those major steps being procedures or tasks. Tasks are made up of actions or steps.

conbody.p: A process is an upper level description of a series of major steps required to accomplish an objective. Processes are generally made up of procedures or tasks. A task is another way of describing a procedure. Another way of putting it is that a process is a sequence of tasks.

DITA does not distinguish between processes and tasks, although
does provide strict task and general task variants of the task information type.

The term task is used in DITA, in preference to procedure, work instruction or unit rule. A task topic contains one procedure or task, and is made up of a series of steps. In turn, steps are made up of commands (or actions), step results, and perhaps substeps.
In a process, each step outlines the result or outcome of a task, and that step is typically linked to the task topic that details that step at a lower level.

section.title: Rationale
section.p:
The Swinburne University of Technology Policies and Procedures database (http://www.swinburne.edu.au/corporate/registrar/ppd/faq.htm#12) uses a three level categorisation, where:
policies regulates, directs and controls actions and conduct
procedures instruct users how to implement a policy at a high level (without detailed instructions)
unit rules (or work instructions) defines the detailed steps for carrying out tasks within a procedure.

Management consultant Gary Eckstein's blog (http://idoinfotech.com/) includes a diagram illustrating the continuum from upper level processes through to lower level work instructions, using a four level taxonomy.

section.p: According to ISO 26514, a procedure is an ordered series of steps that specify how to perform a task, a step is one element (numbered list item) in a procedure that tells a user to perform an action (or actions), an action is the element of a step that a user performs during a procedure, and upper level processes are left undefined. A task is what the user does, and a procedure documents the steps in that task; the user performs a task that the procedure documents.

A similar ontology check whether this word is correct or if taxonomy or vocabulary would be better could be created for steps and actions: the action is what the user does, while the step documents the action.
